Memmeville Feb 26, 1852

My dear dear Sarah

  I have just been reading your very interesting letter, and could you have heard the exclamations of surprise, and enthusastic joy, which continually broke from my overflowing heart, you would have been amused. Sarah sitting up, Sarah sitting in the reading room, Sarah able to raise herself up, how astonishing. I am really so much delighted that I can hardly find words to express my emotions. I arose from the perusal of the letter, collect for my pen and paper, and here you have the answer which my feelings would not suffer unto delay. My dear girl how thankful should you be how good the lord has been to you. I hope and believe you realise it. 
  I had almost given up hearing from you and sat thinking what were the probable reasons why my dear Sarah did not write to me. longing to hear from the place where I spent so many pleasant weeks, when Husband came in with

the letter. My heart sank within for some days when I found there was no letter, for Sarah I loved you with a sisters love. I sometimes almost wish I were not so constituted, as to form such ardent attachments. Still I do not wish so, for it is a source of great pleasure as well as pain. I am glad to hear of the recovery of Mrs Burch and I have had opportunity to recommend Dr Graf several times since my return home, and I do not fail to do it, whenever opportunity offers. My health improves so rapidly as could be expected, with my cares and responsibilities. I have gained much in flesh, and youth, and spirits, although I am now at times considerably nervous. I am now teaching a small school in one of my rooms, of 13 or 15 scholars, four hours a day. This together with the cares of my family exhausts my strength, from day to day, but I hope not to more than exhaust it. That is, not to go beyond my strength. I do very little else that is wearing. 

  I have a dear girl (Sarah) in my school, upon who I lavish as much affection as I did

upon you, when at the water cure. Have three or four young ladies, the rest are children. She is a lovely girl and an active Christian. My dear Sarah let the latter qualifications be yours. I ardently hope you are soon to be restored to the use of your physical powers, and Oh that those powers may be used for the promotion of the piety, of those who may come under your influence. Live my dear girl to do good, you surely cannot be forgetful of your kind Heavenly Father, after thus blessing the means used for your recovery. How much I rejoice with you, and also with the doctor. Give my best respects to him, and tell him I rejoice in his success, and hope for still greater. 

  Remember me to the Kelloggs family, and Miss Seymour, Miss Rogers, and shall I say to dear Ann I love her although she wounded me deeply. If you think best you may say to her that I remember her kindly. But use your own judgment. Now my dear Sarah when you have leasure, and strength, if you will answer this you will oblige me much. Yours in the bonds of true affection.                         
   CC Copeland

Mr Copeland wishes to be remembered to you and also the Dr and others.

 I shall want to hear very much how you get along from time to time, and hope as often as you can you will write without fail. If the going was good, I should be tempted to ride out and see you, but my engagements are such, and the going such, that I cannot consistantly at present. Yours C.C.C.

Wolesville? July 17/54? 

My ever dear Sarah

   I received your mothers kind letter with much pleasure you may be sure, not only because I am always happy to hear from you but because of the encouragement it gave of your restoration to health. May your hopes prove realities. I meant you should have received a letter from me soon after your mother left you for I thought you would feel lonely amongst strangers (though I know you will soon make friends) but something has continually happened to prevent me, but do not think because I have not written, I have not thought about

about you. Indeed my dear Sarah you have a large portion of my thoughts and in spirit I am often with you. Apropos of spirits, if a disembodied spirit can hold communication with a living one why may not living spiritis hold converse with one another (when absent I mean) so if you hear any mysterious knockings or if you furniture is seized with any migratory propensities you may believe (if you please) that it is me wishing to hold converse with you. How ever I had much rather see you face to face, when shall I have that pleasure. I suppose your situation now must remind of Clinton and oh that I could go into your room as easy as I could then, how many questions I should ask. But it is useless to wish and why should we wish to be differently situated when the Providence of God has placed us where we are ----

You I believe have learned the great secret of contentment but I - oh I have many rebellious thoughts. How easy it is to see the right and how hard it is sometimes to do it. Dear Sarah did you ever think that your afflictions have removed you from many temptations with which you might otherwise have been surrounded. I used to sometimes think you knew very little of of the trials of the world and its temptations, but I know that it is not to temptation removed but to temptation overcome that victory is promised, and that in whatever situation of life we are placed we need the help of one that is mightier than we. The weather is extremely warm and s seems to take away the little strength I have. I have been very busy this summer constantly occupied

and though not feeling very well considering how much I have had to do I think I may say my health is tolerable good. Your mother did not give me encouragement of you writing to me very soon and I am sure I could not wish it till you are able but you will write me as soon as the doctor thinks that time has come wont you for I feel very impatient to know how you get along. It is so dark I can scarcely see and I am afraid I have already wearied you. With much love 
I remain your 
Leah

Saratoga Springs Sept _ 1855
Sarah & Cynthia - my Dear Children,

  Long ere this I dare say you have arrived at the conclusion that I had forgotten you or became indifferent about redeeming my promise but neither of these is, I assure you, for you are bound to me by the fondest ties and your memory will ever be cherished with fond recollection, I have neglected writeing more on the account of inability than anything else. I have been failing since nine weeks last Sunday till last Saturday and for two weeks ending last Sunday Mrs. Strong declared there was no chance for me and I see none for myself. The Dr. did not say much about it but I am. That I was supposedly failing, and I had been satisfied for a number of weeks that he never would do me any good. I kept Mr. Nevens posted up how I was but he urged me to stay longer, but I made up my mind to start for home last Saturday and before I got so that I could not get there, but a letter came to me friday night after I had retired to bed from Mr. N requesting me to hand my case over to Dr. S.S. and see what he could do for me - I immediately done so but with some unpleasant feeling on my part, for you know

it is verry sensitive business to change Physicians particularly as we all have been situated here. but what must I do? my life was at stake? and Mr Nevens desired it, for two weeks ending last sunday The least particle of food that I took into my stomach gave me the most excrusiateing agony -- and so had that it was beyond indurance and I was frequently obliged to use means to vomit myself and throw it back Dr. E S felt very bad to have me resort to others for help but said he could not blame me for trying I likewise felt bad for him for I know he tried to cure me and shall ever respect him for it. But the greatest difficulty in my course has ever been over looked. I have ever been confidant of it. My food has sat now much better this week and Dr S S gives much incoriagment of being made better but will not say that I can ever get well. but that I do not expect. I expect now to remain here till the first of Nov. then Dr. S S leaves for Philadelphia it seams hard to me sometimes that I have been deprived of home and friends since a year last June in search of health and now find myself so much worse off than when I started, and got to remain so much longer Dr. Nevens leaves next Tuesday I shall miss her very much for it will reminde one more of home than ever. But this is quite to selfish. routing all about

oneself, but I thought you would want to learn a little the particulars how I got along. please pardon me for it? Mr Nevens health is good he wishes in his letters to be remembered to Mary Sarah & Cynthia. Mary not one of us here has heard one word from since she left for New Hampshire with Robert and Jane. I shall not write you many preliminarys now for I am unable to do, but I am in hopes that I shall feel better next time and I will tell you all about the weather and the market &c &c and there is a number writing to you to day and I suppose they will give you all the interesting detailes that has occured at the prospect mansion since your departure please excuse my pensaling for I write much easer so then otherwise. Miram leaves us tomorrow I am verry sorry to part with her but such is life. But dear Children how oft we are reminded that lifetime is but a school-day, and each day bispeaks to us a world of changes But my paper is limited as well as my strength I received a letter from Mrs. Kellogg last week she was worse than when she left. Please remember my love to that kind Mother of youres and all of your Brothers and Sisters and take a good share to yourselves and my best wishes for your health and happyness Please write when conveinant and tell me how you are getting youres in affectionate remeberance your friend Rachelana Nevens

Misses Sarah & Cyntha Everett 
Remsen
Oneida Co N York

Saratoga Sept -11-53? 

My very Dear friend, 

  Several weeks have passed since we received you kind letter. I assure you we were very glad to hear that your health was as good as when you left. I hope you will not think that I have forgotten you by not writing before by no means, you are not so easily forgotten by your friends. The happy hours spent in your company will be remembered as long as memory retains her seat.  Dear Sarah how much I have missed you O if I could only exchange pen and paper for a seat by your side and tell you all I have to say, But I ought to be thankful for even this resort - if I only knew when to begin you will be surprised to hear of some of the changes that have taken place since you left. True it some two weeks, since by having Miss Howe leave us in place herself under the unclear Dr.  care. She was separated from Miss Gifford for a while though Miss F had lost all the friend she had I was under the anxiety

of doing my best to reconsile her to the seperation altho I felt unpleasant myself. You are aware of the feeling that exists between the patients, but we have tryed to make the best of it. Last Saturday Mrs. Ira Nevens dismissed Dr. L.Y. and has taken the Rev. Dr She is as much embitered against Dr. E.L. as she used to be the Dr. L.Y. the Dr felt very bad. I really pitied him, O how much I have needed you dear one (underlined) to help me encourage the faithless, Mrs Nevens has not seemed to gain any for some weeks and had lost all confidence in what was being done for her I hope it is all for the best. But it makes me feel bad to have them censure him for not curing them. O, for hearts to feel thankful for what we do enjoy Still another is about to take place. Mrs Northrop has just informed me that she is feeling discouraged and tomorrow will make a change. I really feel bad for the Dr, he thinks a great deal of Mrs. N. How shall I find words to comfort the Dr. and quiet the minds of others, all my sympathies are arroused for him, you know how very sensitive he is I trust he will not be forgotten by your family. Mrs Chandler left two weeks ago feeling much better

than when she came, Mrs Green left Saturday feeling quite well, Mrs Sherwood has been gone some time, The rest of the patients are here and quite a number of new ones have been added to our list some good ones too I assure you we have one young gentleman a Mr Knapp who is very agreeable at any rate Miss Row finds him so he came about the time she changed physicians I think he has been the cause of her improving as much as she has she has walked twice a day and taken some pretty lone ones too, but Mr Knapps company shortens the distance of course. The patients are doing very well and seem to enjoy themselves. Emma is well and sends much love and a lot of kisses to Sarah Next Tuesday I shall leave Saratoga for my own dear home I cannot say that I am well but I think I might be if I should stay a while longer I have improved very fast the past four weeks and hope I shall continue to do so after I get home, and now I must say good by hoping you will excuse all errors as I am not in a writing mood to day. My best love to your Mother Mary and Cynthia how much I want to hear from

you all I want to know how you are and all about you be so kind as to let me hear from you soon May you all enjoy heavens choicest blessings is the sincere desire of your true friend 
N.B. Nevens 
Lewiston Maine

ParisHill?, Dec 26/54
Dear Sarah-
Are you ready for another letter? I am if you are not. How did you spend Christmas all alone? or were Aunts there? We had company and Oh dear such a dinner, no [[I eat??} the ones we used to have were not a circumstance to it. How is consider Doctor's cow. does it get enough to eat? What fun we used to have about it. I told mother about that picture we planned and she had a real good laugh. Wont we have a little bit of fun when I come down to see you. I've got a message for you to give our worthy physician if you'll be so kind. If I wasnt afraid that he would be so frightened as never to recover from the shock I'de write a note to him. but you know it wants a whole week before Leap? year and besides how could I commit such an awful rash act

I want you to tell him that I've got something for him something pretty..such that if he'll come up on Paris Hill I'll show it to him, and besides I want to consult him on the expenditure of that thirteen and a half cents that I posess. Now Sarah you must not tell any one, not even the Dr. but I've got a beautiful inkstand for his Shelopoina? and if he'll comes for it he may have it if he dont I'll keep it for my own use. I shant send it to him for any body: would you? You must give my love to all at H.B. and tell Miss Royer if she has not gone home that I send lots of love and I shall write when Lottie comes down. I dreamt about her last night I thought she was almost well and she was dressed up in the top of the fashion to go out for a walk she had a monstrous open bonnet on. She

looked comical enough I can assure you. How is that poor back of yours Sarah can you sit up yet. My knee is better than it was before I fell and getting strong every day is'nt that good news. shall come down before two months are gone I guess. now write soon Lottie will send a note with this and both will be as much as you had ought to read. Good bye- Emma
My dear Sarah
Em's betrayed her character poorly I think in being so selfish as only to leave me this little bit of paper to write on. I've been teasing her for this last five minutes to be quick and get through. I want to tell you in the first place I dont believe you'll be able to read this and if you cant you must get Nette to read it for you. How did you get along last Saturday? Did R? come up? I suppose I shall get an answer a week from Monday when I come down. You dont know what extravagant Christmas present, Em and I got - from "the Polish gentleman" too. I dont believe you'd

guess if you were to try from now to New Years. It was neither more nor less than a stick of candy apiece. We are both trying to think of something for a New Year's present for Anne but we cant hit upon anything that seems exactly the thing. Tell Anne that I am in a fair way of rivalling her, for I gave Em? her footbath and she says Mr. B. I do footbaths.  Christmas Eve I went to Claryville with father to church. Just think of riding five miles there that stormy day and then five miles back that dark night. Dont you think we had plenty of courage? Tell Nellie?? that I saw Frank Scott, Fannie Babcock and Louise Luce and that I heard that Purdy was in Raidyeation yet. Mother is in a great hurry for me to finish. Last Monday I went to Utica. Didnt I have a cold time? Our donation, it seems, isnt too far off just yet. I had a real pleasant time ?? since I've been home. I've not gone any where, but have just staid quietly at home and worked. Of course Nellie is very busy just now or I'm sure she would have written to me. When you see this note I'm sure you'll wonder why I didnt take the prize last term for writing. Give my love to Miss Royce and Mrs. Copland.  Goodbye Lottie
Miss. S. Everett-

The night before Thanksgiving at the parsonage, Nov. 26th, 1859.
Dear Sarah,
If you could only see the lots of good things that are on the table and see Mother as busy as a bee, not making houney? to be sure but stuffing the turkey. O, wouldn't you wish you'd been invited up to our house. Sometimes in my life I have seen an old picture of the night before Christmas. The old woman is very busy making a huge plum pudding and sewing it up in a canvass bag while seated on a chair with its front paws on the table is an old cat evidently anxiously waiting for his share of the good things. Whilst underneath was this beautiful poetry 

 King Solomon, he a pudding did make a pudding did make
 He tied it up in a canvass bag and stuffed it well with plums

Now this is almost a fac simile of the night before Thanksgiving in this house but instead of its being a pudding it is a nice fat turkey. What are you doing to night Sarah? Is the Dr. in your room sitting on that chair by the bed side trying to look into your face but can't because it is so nicely shaded by the books. I'de knock them down if I was only there. Arnt you glad I'm not?  What is he saying Sarah? Nothing soft or sweet I hope? not yet anything, about me

or my knee? By the by I'm afraid it is you not me who has got to hurry I can raise my foot from the ground and yesterday I took three or four steps without my crutch and it did not make my knee sell at all. just think of that Sally dear? When I come to see you I guess I shall go with a cane and I shall come along the hall so still and rap at your door; you'll say come and in will walk not hop Emma what a meeting that will be. If you are only able to sit up. I'm so glad you are getting strong. But what are you doing Sarah have I guessed right? or is Anna and her knitting there sitting on the floor close to the stove to keep warm; or are you all alone wishing that the how do you do rapp would make itself audible on the celing beneath you. But you wont hear it to night Sarah;  Emma is five miles away and if she should rap you would not hear her so think of something else dear not home though that would make you feel worse than any thing else you are a mind to. the fire is sparking all the time to night as if Ann was sure she'd look up so  rogish and say, "It's a sign of marriage". I hope it will be fine to morrow dont you? You wont get this if it isnt cause -- cause why. I suppose you're thinking I'm dreadfully excited but youre very much mistaken I never felt more calm

or composed in my life though once in a while I wonder - as who doesn't - what the morrow will bring forth; good or evil as it may be. I shall not finish this till to morrow so shall keep you in advance of the times. Father is giving a temperance adress to night on the Hall, the children are gone, so mother and I am alone. Good night Sarah. Dont you here the crutch? as it used to was. I shall get up early to morrow morning so once more a fond good night. 
Friday
Dear Sarah -- the to morrow has gone and nought is left but the yesterday of to day; another meeting and another parting; a few more & soon will come the Last -- the last --how mournfully it sounds -- how mournful it would be, were it not for the promis of that better land where partings are unknown. No sickness there, -- No weary wasting of the frame away, No fearful shrinking from the midnight air No dread of Summer hot & fervid ray. No hidden grief -- No wild and cheerless vision of despair No vain insisting  for a swift relief No tearful eyes, no broken hearts are There. I believe I'm almost as bad as your crazy patient I don't do any thing but make mistakes just see what a blunder I made up there. hand -- image I'm almost ashamed

to send this scribble to you. wont you please excuse it? I had a real good visit yesterday with --------------------- -------------------- I hope the Dr enjoyed himself I was rather disappointed in not getting a letter from you but accepted your excuse very cheerfully. I meant to have finished this but did not find time. Of course I wanted to spend all the time possible with the company It seems as lonely as it did when I first came home, but I shall get over it. Write as soon as possible. Give my love to all the good folks. Yours for ever -- Emm
P.S. The Dr wishes that, that little Sarah would get along as fast as I do. Em.

Camp 38th Rgt. U.S.C.T
T.Roy ?? 25th A.C.
March 22nd 1865
Dear Friend Sarah
I cannot have a quiet conscience unless I immediately write to my dear friend Sarah. Nothing but interruptions of various kinds has detered me until this hour. It is not because I have forgotten you my friend no no time nor distance can never erase my friends from my memory. when I tell you what has been going on and all the work.."in our line." What we have done for the past two months I think you will measurably pardon my long silence. I am in very good health to night feeling much better than I did last night. Sarah I received your letter dated January 14th some time since and a more welcome missive never came to me since I left home. Letters from my friends are better to me

than my meals are it matters not how hungry I am. Lieut George Everett is well Lieut Roberts has gone home on a leave of (15) fifteen day expected to be married while at home. The weather is most beautiful at this time and the roads are in perfect order. and portions of the army are in motion but the two Divisions 1 & 2 of the 23rd A.C. that is here have no orders as yet in regard to marching. Our Corps is receiving large numbers of Recruits. My Regt is very near (1100) Eleven hundred strong and all the officers that we have is just six (6) while we are entitled to (33) thirty three. I have command of (175) one hundred seventy five men. Lieut Racon the same number. I have just one man in my company who is able to help me with my books. Don't you think that we have very near all the duties to perform that we can perform with any perfection. Well the war news is very interesting dont you think. Sherman is doing well with his army. Genl Sheridan is at work very near Richmond. and I have an idea that the army of the James will swing around and

form a junction with his (Sheridans) Army. In order to do that we would have to leave our works and go to the right. The 24th Corps is under marching orders. The enemy are deserting Lee's army very fast. I dont know the exact number but I know that a very large number has come in. in our front in the last two months, They all tell the same story that the majority of the people south want the war to close. Sarah I would have enjoyed your donation very much could I have been there. I hope to attend the next also hope that the war will be at an end. Cousin Sarah you ask how we spend the Sabbath. Well last Sabbath morn we had Roll Call at day Break, company inspection at 8 o:clk.a.m. Regimental inspection at 10 A.M. Brigade inspection at 12. Division inspection at 2 P.M. Division Dress Parade at 3 P.M. and Division Review at 4.P.M. do you think we had time to attend church that Sabbath. This is very near the way all Sabbaths are in the army. How I would like to attend a good prayer meeting. I am doing the best I can Gods grace assisting me. Let your unworthy friend have and interest in your prayers.How is your Mother & Father. enjoying good health I hope and pray

I have before me a letter from Cynthia also one from Jennie yet unanswered. I feel very bad Girls to think that I have delayed writing thus long. but I hope that you will overlook all and remember me as ever your sincere Friend for I am and always will be. Tell Jennie I have not forgotten the heavy hand. There is Mary and Anna I dont hear very often from them. They are my sisters of course they are. Well now how is this. I think somewhere in my letter I called Sarah my cousin. this will never answer She is a Sister of course She is. When I am asked how many Brother and Sister I have, I say (8) Eight Sisters & well I forget how

many Brothers I have got. I received a letter from sister Sarah Anne a few days since I think her people were all well She was in Ronville. is at home before this I presume. How is Eddie. I dont think he can say now that I am owing him a letter. Just the other way now. I am expecting one from him. Sister Mary Ann is out west dont know how long she will stay. She is enjoying herself very well I am on duty to night as Regimental Officer of the day I am responsible for the whole Regt. and have just been out and quieted some talkers as there are always some who do not regard orders. By the way we have a new Colonell in our Regt R M Hall.

Sarah I would like to just step into Master Everett’s house to right now directed talk I hope the time is not far distant when I can meet you all around the fireside Before I close this letter let me humbly ask an interest in all your prayers that I may by guided at all times by the holy spirit and at last meet you all around Gods throne in Heaven.

 My kind regards to all that enquire after me but Principally to Mother & Father Everett, Sister Jennie, Mary Cynthia Anna  also Eddy Retain a portion for yourself for I am with much free? yr friend 
 Wm Ames

Osawatomie Sept 28 1870
Dear Aunt Sarah 
I thought I would write to you this morning. They have all gone to Paola to the counly fair but me. I sland home to get up the cattle tonight. I thought I had better stop home because it may be late when they get home. does Thomas Hughe work for Grandpa yet. don't you think this is a long pies of paper for me to write on I have to put words as fra apart as it will do I had a little pig about fore or five weeks ago that I traded to Frank for a revolfaer?. Father and Frank took one of Mr Snow's
horses so I have got one to ride to town. good by From your affectionate nephew R.C.E.

Turin
Jan. 28th 1878
Dear Sister Sarah & all
I haven't forgotten that I received a letter from you just before Christmas those pieces you sent were very good one of them was spoken the pieces were selected before things came Mrs. Ler's class of little boys ten in number spoke a piece entitled "Ten Little Potato Bugs" Carroll & Charlie spoke well. Our winter has been very mild so far I think most of the people go with sleighs To-day it has been a bitter cold day. Carroll wanted

to go to school he tells his Father he will want a second reader soon he has been steady one term and three weeks of another and commenced reading in the P. Primer when the term was half out - he commenced in First Reader he was spelling Butterfly and telling the definition at night. He thinks a great deal of his teacher Charlie & I visited the school one afternoon Charlie was asking me a few days ago if Uncle Williams hand was well. We were very glad to get Jennie's letter it seemed a long time since we have heard from you. I ask Edward quite often for a letter he says " then can you expect letters when I don't write"

We have nine hens get fresh eggs every day this is the first winter that we have had fresh eggs they came very good as I did not pack? any in the fall. We have services at our  church every sunday by the Rev. James Jarrett he seems to be liked very much. we are to have  a dinner socible? at Mr. A. H. Ls? Thursday eve for the benefit of the Presbyterian Church Sarah Lyman is very much better gets out to Sabath school Edward seems quite like a new man and he weighs more than he has since we were married he seems bright & happy all of the time.

I must send Anna a sample of the diferent plants I have in blossom, would like to see some of you up here Sarah I think Doctor Jones has more practice since he done so well with Edward he has had two patients with fever the second house below here have been sick eight weeks I guess I had better stop and get warm. How is Mother this winter hope she can make us a visit before long. has your cough entirely left you? I hope I shall hear from you soon love to all I remain your sister Mati 
P.S. This has been a good winter for John Eddie to go to school E. comes home quite early now for him 

 Mate

Do you remember seven years ago tomorrow night about three oclock 

Mate

Mrs. James Allen from Constableville was assisting here a few days ago I ask her how they liked their school teacher she said very she didn't really know that we were acquainted with him

Home, March 17, 1879.
My dear Sisters. –

 We received the enclosed letter from Uncle N. to Jennie last Saturday at the same time as Mary's letter, and the note from Rev. G. C. E. I will send this last to brother Eddie tomorrow, as it seems best to me to get his opinion of the matter before sending any word out. I got a letter from him, a few days ago, saying he had not quite finished his arrangements at home, so he could leave yet. – but hoped to in a few days. So we do not know yet how soon he will start. I have been getting some of the Bills filled out – have got all those of this State and some other done. I do not think it would be best to try to get 

in margins:
will do with it but Wm. is able to go to R. tomorrow he will take it and try to do the best he can – either send or sell. It will not do to keep it as he may not be able to go down for some time. A little then might shut us up. We hope to finish Mothers tub this month. Do you think butter wold sell better if it was colored? That opinion seems to be gaining ground here. We have not tried it yet. I do not cough nearly as much as I did especially nights I feel stronger and have more heart to make plans for next summer. I am

the Postal Cards printed here. I have said nothing to Lewis about E's proposed trip - thought it would be as well for him to tell him when he comes. I will write to E. and ask him to let you know what he thinks about Mr. Edwards' proposition. Will that do? Did you write to Dewi Emlyn? as you proposed. I hope you will let me know when you hear from him. I hope Dr. Thomas, Liverpool, is not going to fail of keeping his promise. Has Dr. Thomas, Pittsburg, written any thing? or any of the ministers?  Wm hopes to be able to go to the village tomorrow so I am writing this evening to send with him. We do not get the mail every day now since George went away, and so have to watch our chance. David Price has promised to bring it for us when we are not able to get it ourselves. He brought your letter Saturday. Celia 
along the sides and top:
quite hoarse yet. but not as bad as when Jennie went away. I have not been able to sing in the church for a good many weeks. I hope my voice will return when warm weather comes. Do you think it will. Wm is getting better slowly. He is able to do the chores but it is pretty hard work for him. His back troubles him a good deal and he looks badly. I think perhaps he has

Roberts' Mother was buried last Tuesday. I went to the funeral afoot as the roads were too soft to take a horse. I staid at Gwen's that night, and came up on the crust the next day – and so did not get so very tired. I went to Mrs. Elias Jones' on my way home, and took dinner there. Rev. E.R. Lewis preached in our church yesterday morning – but we did not go, as it was stormy, & Wm did not feel able. It was pleasant in the evening, and I went on the crust. The snow is still very deep, though it settled some during the thaw last week. Today we have been having a fresh supply but we flatter ourselves that it will be short-lived. The prayer meeting this week is at Wm H. Williams', tonight, next week it will probably be at Lewis'. How does Jennie get along with her class letters. When she finishes those, we shall hope to hear from her again.

We hear tonight that Marrie Evans was married last Saturday night to some one from Waterville.

We do not feel just right - if we do not hear often a little from each of you. Mr. Hughes called here the other day, but I did not say any thing to him about the Article for the Cenhadwr, as I really didn't know what to say. Has Jennie sent any thing to him? - With Anna's permission I write a few words in her letter. Wm. & I are not very faithful in answering letters. This year we got the first egg March 13. Perhaps some time we can do something in that way or as you suggest with something else lighter than common farming, but I don't see as we can this year. Turin Feb. 20th 1880
My Dear Sisters
We were glad to hear once more from the City. I have not felt much like writing and Edward has a great deal to do. Mr Lewis being sick he has to help load lumber + do a great deal of his business, last week he was about sick. Mother keeps quite smart, the boys are well from their colds, Charlie has had the Croup they too have not felt much like writing. Carroll came home from school last Friday pleased to think he had spelt the school down + two boys from upstairs were down and spelled with them. I presume he will write to John Eddie about it; Maggie was here last week had a very pleasant visit with her. I walked out this pleasant morning and called on one of my neighbors it does not tire one to work. following words are lined through: I do not think I overdone in anything the chills I had in Remsen I have now

Monday P.M. Edward is resting he has a good deal of headache & cough some I have been giving him Sulphur he has had it very hard since May- has been sick so many people come to settle, they often call for him before he gets away from the house in the Morn. Mr. L. is better now hope it will be some easier for him. Mother keeps quite smart, Charlie stays with his mama and pleasant mornings we take a short walk. Edward has been so busy of late that I thought a short walk would give me a chance to breathe the fresh air. Cena & Abbie have their pictures taken together and sent them to us they are very good, their families are well.
Please remember me to Cousin N. White when you see her again. I know you will like her she is always very pleasant.

How it is blowing and snowing out quite a change in the weather we can afford to have some storm we have had such beautiful weather so far the roads good early all of the time. I must tell you that Mrs. Davis called on us twice last week (Owen ?'s sister) she said (they missed you all so much) The boys went to Sabbath School yesterday and are getting to be quite little men. Charlie wants me to write to Aunt Sarah & tell her his teeth are just coming in here --they were knocked out last summer. We read Mary's letter to day was glad to hear that you all were pretty well. hope J.E. will write us what they think of his head. I hope he will make a good man whatever occupation he follows Hope you can make out to read this my pencil is poor I think Charlie will write before long He think those pictures will with lots of love to each of you from us all.                

        Your Sister Mary Allen Everett

Turin March 23rd 1881
Dear sister Sarah
I thought as you had nothing to-do but to read letters &c. I would write to you again and you know it is a good way for me to improve any time. Mother has been down home for over a week now. I hope she can come back before Edward goes over in Greig to stay several days at a time. The roads are getting very bad and he thinks it would be better for him to stay. Mr. Lewis does not go out much now although he keeps about the same. I left this yesterday to copy a piece for Carroll He takes part in the exhibition a dialogue

The title is "Scenes in a Backwoods School" Carroll is teacher I wish you might be here to hear him. We had some of those dried blackberries for tea that we bought at the time we went for ride. Do you remember how nice we found the berries beyond the Forest Church? I think they were the nicest I ever saw. I think it would be nice to go over the river and catch nice trout in fish creek. I think we will have to try it some time. I am glad you can eat maple sugar for I think it is very good for you. Dr. Johnson told me last spring to eat all I wanted as it was very good for one, I do not care as much for it this spring  Jimmie brought us about 3 lbs. to have sugar on snow the boys enjoyed it very much as well as we. My tomato

are up quite nice over 50 plants I think some of transplanting them when they get a little larger and take a great deal of pains with them and when it comes time to set them out I am going to ask 5 cents for each (What do you think of it.) Mrs. Lewis does not think of sowing any seed and nearly every year has had from 13 to 20 from us for nothing I have been willing she should have them. Now I shall take extra pains with them. Please write me what you think of it. Anna: does it look small? Mrs. Vankory  was around the other day getting dirty kid gloves to clean She ask 12 1/2 cents for cleaning she said she thought she would like to earn a little. I am making some feather trimming to sell I ask 10 cents a yard for it - the same

that I learned to make at Brant. Charlie is crying on the sofa asleep with his spelling book before his eyes Carroll is doing examples in Arithmetic his Father is helping him. I have been turning my black alapaca this spring the one I wore so much while you were here and it looks quite fresh, and how do you think I am gong to loop it up I am going to put the skirts on Edward this eve. Your friends in Turin often enquire for you and want to know when you are coming back I tell them when the snow is gone & the roads are settled. I hope you will not read all of this letter at a time for I am afraid it will make you feel bad  Anna are unclear any of those flower seeds to be put in the earth soon.? if so which ones. Dont you think it would be better for me to write postals and it wont be quite so tiresome to read: Love to each one of you hopeing to hear often how you all are. 

 Mate

Transcriber's note: "Mate" is a nickname for Mary A. Allen, who married Sarah's brother Edward W. Everett.  RMR

433 W. 34th St.
  June 28 1881

Dear Sister Sarah: 

  I really feel honored in receiving a letter from you this morning, written by your own hand. You really seem to be gaining nicely. Hope this warm weather will set you up ever so much. Keep up good cheer dearie, and keep on improving just as fast as possible. Make hay while the sun shines.  That is the way to do it. I am feeling a good deal better. I'm fat enough to make me ashamed of ever complaining. "They...

say that I am looking much better. Weigh only 133 1/2 lbs! Does not that sound frail? When you get up to 125 I shall be satisfied!! Wish I could be there to see Mate & Eddie. Hope you will all have a nice visit. Did I tell you that I had a call in Feb. I think or March from Mate's cousin Mrs. White & her Father Dr. Avery? It was soon after Mrs. Avery's death. I intended to call and see them before they went to the country, but lost their address. Had promised to send them an invitation to our Commencement & began to address one to Dr. Avery

but that was as far as I could go. Have since found the card, but it was after the first of May, when I supposed they would be in the country. How nice that word sounds, country! It makes my mouth water. Two of the Trustees of the College were in this morning to talk over college matters. They seem to like suggestions &c. from even a little lady like me! I hope we will have a flourishing time next winter. If you have any students on hand send them to our College! John E. wrote me that he might possibly go to

Hamilton College next winter. Do you think he will? If so I suppose I may as well say good bye to my fond dreams of having my folks with me in New York. It may be best so I hope at least that we may be guided aright. Dana has just been in to enquire &c. He says he is studying awful hard this summer Is reading Xenophon. He is going to try & write to the boy. He says that one advantage of this College is that when through with the drilling here, one is fittest for practical life. He copied the questions of the examinations & tucked them in my window one day. Will I send them in my last? Cannot lay my hand on them now. He says if he went to enter coll next fall, he must

study awful hard this summer. Elder did not pass. Dana did, but did not rank so high as he would have liked to. Dana said 2 of their class got prizes. McBruce & a little slim red headed fellow whose name he did not remember. The valedictorian got along very nicely till he got mid-stream & then had to take out his notes to help him through. Nice boys, these companions of Eddie's are. I enjoy having them call. Now Sallie, I hope you will be able to drop me a line again before very long. Hope my long yarn does has not wearied you overmuch. Will try to run home as soon

as I can, but do not wear out your eyes looking. May be some time. Much, much love to one & all.
Mollie

New Graefenburg March 24th 1862? 

Dear friend Sarah, 

  I have delayed sometime in writing you & also your sister Mary, for it has been my mind to try & visit you. But we have found a great deal to ocupy out time since I wrote before. We are all in comfortable health, it is a blessing I think we realize & hope that we are truly thankful to our Heavenly Father for it. My thoughts often are turned to your people & the  many kindness you have shown in any way, I hope that you will never be left to suffer, for the want of friends If our trust is in God we need not fear, He alone, is able to carry us through dangers, both seen & unseen, where have you been this winter, also your other sisters. I should like to hear from them all. Your youngest brother

where is he, Has he gone to the battlefield, or any of your brothers, We have great changes all around us, many families have been broken, on account of our country's troubles But the overruling hand of Providence seems plainly to be seen, And to us it seems, that the death blow to slavery has been struck. What do you think about it? Was not Gen'. John C. Fremont as near right as Gen'. McClellan is? but he has acted nobly) He has gained friends this way they are willing if his life is spared I hope it may be to have him President next But his is looking ahead some way, Why has every thing 3¢ stamp covers text still along the Potomac so long stamp obscures but we shall find out before long.) I will tell you the present situation we are in, & will ask some questions which if convienant would like a reply. Our minister, Re D.R. Barnes has been sick all winter & we have been without a minister, but have had Reading meetings, when the going has been so we could attend, but feel

the importance of keeping up religious worship. The thought has struck me would your father be willing to preach to us one Sabbath or is he so situated he cannot it would be a treat? if he could We have been hopeing, Mr Barnes would be well enough soon to fill his place as yet his health is quite feeble. You know our sentiments & perhaps have heard of the troubles we have had, We assemble at the Norwich School house & for 10 years in April have been a happy band. The gospel has been faithfuly preached & the good Lord has been sown Many of the young people are very anxious to hear preaching My own anxiety has been such had it not been for the want of means, I would have come & paid my board, to have spent one Sabbath to hear preaching, Spiritualism is around us, & is doing great injury. I hope & pray that it may not enter our "little flock", I have been told by Mrs. John Davis, that all in "New Graefenberg" are Spiritualists. But I am sorry to say it, think it must be true. Those who are not, stamp covers text short time here when they come, But stamp that truth will rise & error & delusion be stamp We need the prayers of Christian friends [stamp]] keep us from falling into its fatal stamp is a consolation in knowing th[stamp]] "Lord" reign's.  "Le the earth rejoice? If it were not for the "Bible" what comfort could we have in this trying time, I must write a few lines to your sister Mary "as I directed my unclear to her, Do come & see me this summer as I expect to be the home girl, Please give my love to your  sisters I should like much to see them all, & your parents too, It would be welcomed by all of us. With much love to you, I remain your friend   C. E. Warriner

  March 26

Dear friend Mary, Perhaps you have wondered my not answering the reseption of the paper you sent, it came at the right time,, One reason why I sent for a 'Welsh paper" was on Mothers" account, The war "news was so trying to her there that it would make her sick to read it, & I thought something she could not exactly understand would 
in left margin:
The Welsh here are tried as well as we with Spiritualism.

be quite as good for here, You would have been amused to hear her read Welsh" I am inclined to think you would have laughed some  I have tryed some to get a Subscriber for you but have not yet succeeded,

Victoria & myself have been home the most of the winter. Frances is in Springfield Mass. We expect her home in April She left home last Oct, It has made the winter seem longer than usual!  Are you all married & your husbands in the Army? I feel some anxious to know. Frances has been taking & giving lessons on the 'Melodian" & thinks she shall like music as an additional branch in teaching.  Victoria will teach this summer, & I some think Frances will too. 
 While I am trying to learn Dress Making have learnt to cut by 'Diagram' hope it will not be an entire fuiture, my health quite good. How is yours? My brothers wife was very sick & her sister came from Mass. & took care of her last spring she has a fine little girl They call her "Abby Alice"  You may think strange my wishing to know if you was able to be a Nurse, But I thought she was such a great woman if she did well you would be just the one, her babe was brought up on a bottle has never made but little trouble  My paper is nearly full, so I must close. I should be happy to see you & your sisters too. With much love to you I remain your friend 
  Cordelia to. Mary

PS At present the going is quite bad We have been having a great deal of ice

 March 31 Yesterday I listened to a Mr Abby a Minister who preached from the text unclear What he said I like much. The affect of this discours was to aid a society founded to introduce the Bible as a seperate study & no student can graduate from any school without thorough understanding the Bible (I should have said Aecumenical school) He said this had been neglected & mentioned several cases where he had called they could not find the unclear Chap he was going to read. Otherwise they were accomplished scholars.

Roberts Ranch March 7
My much cherished cousin Sarah:

 I have not the least doubt you would like to hear your California cousin Anna?-- now you shall have it just as it is -- now in my calm sober mind; when I exchange this dull Ranch life for one of the City so that I can give you something of the City doings Jenney & Mary may look for a letter from me.
 I came as you well know with the full determination to do what my "hands findeth to do" that resolution has not been broken. It is not in our power to order events. I must give you a brief summary of my life in this country.
  I came with mother to the ranch, a Spanish word, for a farm; we are termed ranchers. I set my self about sewing as fast as possible, made a dozen bed-quilts without

a frame. I leave you to judge rather a slow way — I sewed seven or eight pieces of cloth into various things for the house — During part of this time the whole valley was
inundated, the water was not in the house but was within an inch of the floor, this was so far six weeks — from eight to ten inches deep in the yard, carrying some of the rails
quite a distance, the men are now repairing the fence for the making of a garden — We were worse off then Noah in the "Ark" — Father found it very difficult to keep a live his
Hogs - near the hay-stack a platform was raised, to keep them from the water, feeding them with boiled barley, several died

he drove his horses, and mules, ten miles off on to Cache creek one of the best farming districts in the State- As for milk have not had nor seen a drop, for three months- milch cows are very high, ranging from a hundred to a hundred and fifty dollars-.when the water abated so that the river was in its banks, the ground soon dried, and grass sprung up-; now the first of March looks like your May - the yellow butter cups have opened their petals - forming a happy blending with the green grass - the air is mild and balmy. fanning us with the southern breeze, which at this time of the year is a sure prognostication of coming rains - togeather with a few showers in April is the sum in toto until November -
There is no earthly bliss without some alloy, mosketoes are now flying around in all directions, but not the tenth part of what is to come - and fleas too in numbers far to great these have formed a tenatious attachment to me which is not reciprocated -
Now to return to myself - at the close of high water had my work finished, and thought I was ready to go to the City - The dampness arising from the water and the full play it had from the openess of the house togeather left me soley to enjoy the Rheumatism in my lame limb - so that I have been obliged to resort to my cot some of the time -have tried every thing that was in my reach - now am using warm water and Dr. Kellingers liniment - yesterday took a short walk - am agoing to day - as for house work have done but little - I am in strong faith recovering, - it is a very prevalent complaint in this country -

A short time since our trunks came safe just 92 days sail in the clipper ship Flying fish, from New York, to San. Francisco by way of the Horn - for freightage $9.00 very much cheaper than if they came with us - and in as good order as when packed - we regret now we did not have more things come round -.
Have not spoken to a woman since New Year's - have seen three or four pass the house - there are some living up and down the river; they have not called on us nor we on them, work first, and work last is the tune in this country, greater inducements are held out in this land of Gold, and poverty - it is a great place to make and the same to lose money - at times there is an emense deal of suffering - this winter provisions were extremely high - in the country adjacent to this  - very much higher in the mountains among the miners - The only way of access to some of the trading posts - is with packed mules - when I was at your place had not seen a mountain - now can see them in the distance - The coast range - snow can be seen on the tops of the highest peaks - we have splendid sun set views - the sun going behind this range of mountains - that divides from the broad sweeping waves of the Pacific - On our east the willow woven banks of the Sacramento - upon its surface plies steam-boats up and down daily - sometimes we can see the Indian canoe not many in valley -

  Dear mother has a large share of hard work quite to much, from a dozen to fifteen in the family - doing all the work her self - she has made some excellent corn bread

Darling Evit
It is after nine o'clock and I'm so tired you'll forgive me wont you if i dont write very much this time?
You know my ear was sore when you were here its been "worser" I went to see a Dr and he said it was a carbuncle its better now. I had a letter from Mr. Fiske to night one from Amanda and one from Will. Did'nt I feel joyfull   To night I had Jennie on the board and I said who is this Jennie? "Miss Mantin" no Sarah. "Sawer" she said. Sarah who? I asked next "Sawer Miss Mantin" she said in her cunning way. When I ask her where Evit is she look sober and says "done, home". This afternoon I copied off the windows and washed all the paint in my room. I have'nt got things to rights yet but when I do wont it be fine? You'd laugh if you could see
top margin
was yours or mine I'm so sleepy Good night and pleasant dreams. Much love to your dear Sister Lovingly your friend 'Sarah Miss Mantin'

the table and room now. The spread is all up in a heap on the table, on one corner is your humble servant scribbling and beside there is the lamp, two bottles, two ink wells a pair of gloves my pocket book, tatting box, brush, comb, three letters, books pin cushion etc. etc. I dont mean these things are all scribbling as you might suppose by the way it reads but they are on the table.
Mr. Ford has been writing in my extract book, and that reminds me that you have never written in it I'm so sorry.
This has been such a lovely day. 
Mr. & Mrs Sumner were here to dinner. Mr. S. was a funny as ever  I have written down just what came into my head first. Clifton Springs
  June 3d

Dear Sarah—

  During a few months past I have been on a visit at the West — as far as the State of Wis. Spent a week at the city of Milwaukee with a patient of mine — on my return I found a letter from your sister Mrs. Butler asking some questions in regard to your coming here as a patient this session or fall. 
 Well Sarah I have not a single doubt but that you might receive benefit from a judicious course of water treatment but how much benefit not how long a time it wold require I am unable now to say but it is my impression that it would be necessary for you to stay here at least 12 months to receive anything like a permanent benefit.

I think you would be made able to walk all about and enjoy a very fine degree of health again - I would not say that you can become well but comfortable - so well as to be all about the house - in the garden &c &c —

 We would need in any mild course of water treatment and at the same time particular attention should be paid to the local difficulty - If the prolapsus was overcome you would be able to stand on your feet and walk - the spinal irritation is kept up by the local disease and will trouble you so long as the latter disease remains - I am satisfied as to this and I have had a pretty good opportunity of watching your case —
 All the difficulty of the head which you consistently experience arises from the above cause —

Do not understand me to say that this local disease is all the disease you have - Of course there is an actual disease of the spine but I would be understood to say that the spinal disease has produced and is now kept up by the local difficulty - If then the local disease was cured this irritation would be take off from the spine and it become restored to a healthy condition - 
  My object in visiting Milwaukee was to select a site for a Water cure Establishment - I succeeded in finding one to suit me and made a purchase of 12 acres of land near the city - distance 2 1/2 miles - a beautiful walnut grove and all in sight of Milwaukee a city of 30000 people and growing rapidly - Several gentle men there have taken notes? with me and we have already about $7000 worth of the stock taken up.

We want $12000 - I intend to lease them in the fall - perhaps in September, and commence building immediately I am now making the plan - it will accommodate 80 patients and perhaps 100 - my wife is now and has been for the last year preparing herself for the treatment of all female diseases - she is making rapid progress. We shall be able to open the house I hope about the first of April next.

 So you see Dear Sarah that if you were here now you would be under my care only about three or four months - but Dr Fortin? will be here and he is able to do all for you tht I can -- and perhaps more - But after all I shall not urge you coming here very strongly - I think you will not improve at home - it would of course require some time then at a cure but my impression is that as you grow older your disease not? get better. - I shall want to see you before I go West and prescribe for you again - Please let me hear from you soon and let me just now give care -  can you write the letter yourself - I wish you would do so if possible -- Mrs. G. writes with me in care to you and the family —
 Yours very truly
  James E. Grafs

Carr's room 8 O'clock at night 

Dear Sarah - 

       "Long as I live I shall love to call you so" Oh the unspeakables & sorrow, the severest pangs, the Heavenly? bitterness, have I experienced this day by being seperated from the dearest joy of my heart, - you. 

The tear has once forced itself into the corner of my eye, and the corner of my apron been once in requisition. Oh the bitterness of eating the bread of sorrow drawing of man with title Cranston Best thanks to Morse for the telegraphic invention. The crutch has but to rap when Lo! the message is returned. It is to be hoped the inhabitants will not be alarmed, thinging the spirits of the departed are hovering near. O dear Sarah do not judge of the depth of my affection by my epistles for nothing ever bore so wide a relation as my love and my letter 
Hoping to hear from you soon I bid you good night and send a Kiss mark Emma

Miss Sarah Everett

Dear Sarah,

   Your letter was eagerly read yesterday morning, but so much gratitude frightened me as much as the pin did you, for how can I ever be inferior to my sister, and if she sends so much thanks for one pin, what shall I say to fourteen such dainty ones too. Oh dear, dear, what shall I say? - nothing - so please imagine it all and make me as grateful as you please. - I am glad you and Eddie are pleased and am only sorry you have not been able to visit Mary Kellogg, it will not be so easy to go to Rome. I wish you could visit your friends more, it would do them and you good, but the position of "only daughter at home" will, perhaps, not admit of it. Wouldn't we like to 

written across top
We are sure that papers look pretty on the kitchen, though it did not show very well in the piece. Thank you for sending it we can imagine how it looks some we have no fear it will be soiled before we see it, if we go home this summer. Have you also painted the kitchen? if so what color?
We wish when you write next to Pierce and Owen just tell them about Galesburg and if they wish to face the western country this is the place. Sarah, I wish I could give you some idea how pleasant this spring has made this place everything looks so green. We have had a great deal of rain but today's loveliness leaves the 'past to bury its dead'. The streets are muddy otherwise the rainy past is forgotten. We hope Anna will continue to improve. Love to Nellie, Georgie and all. We will try to send likenesses next time.

ease your labors a little especially of sewing Cen.! You talk of a "weak team" I can't think who there is to make a team at all. Only one horse can I call to mind and that is the only &c. Mother, surely cannot sew with her lame back! and Nellie -  there I have it - you have hitched her into the traces. Have you finished that nine hundred yet? It doesn't seem right that you should try to do so much, could you not get some of the good friends to come and help you? I have half a mind to send Anna home or resign myself that we may both go and help you. What say you? I have not much to do. Only about a dozen young ladies are here at present. The majority of the pupils reside here and of course do not board in the Sem. Times are hard and many are trying to keep up their studies at home this summer, who expect to return next

fall. Others have gone to teach, so you must think of me no more as very busy or wearing myself out. There is not usually much done the lost part of this term and I expect by vacation to be fresh and strong enough for anything I hope when pa comes to know just how little I do he will think better of the Kansas project. I do not think it best for Anna to go as she can so pleasantly return with father. By the way, why does not mother come with father. It would do her so much good and will be a chance she may never again have to visit Uncle David. Do try, please, and persuade her to come. We want very much to see her and Anna says if she could only see both of our dear parents she would be counted to pass the vacation at Uncle's without going home till she graduates. So you see it would be no expense for me to come. As I expect

ed to pray for Anna. I would just as soon and sooner pay for ma. So there, mother dear, will you not come? 

  How long has aunt been with you? you have said nothing about it before. Does she seem contented in the house, or do you have to watch her all the time? Where does she sleep? O, how I wish she might get better. Does she ever speak of us, if so, please give our best love to her and tell her we do not forget her. -- Has Uncle Hughes moved to Western? We found in the Cen, the account of the death of Hannah Hughes, is it his brother's wife? It must be a great loss to him and his little ones. What will they do, poor things? -- Mr. James' children are also left motherless again. O, sister, where I think of so many who lose their mother while so young my heart rises in gratitude to God, and I love our mother more. God bless and preserve her long to us! and God help us love her truly! I know I am not worthy of so good a mother but I do think I value her a little. Let us all try to make her as happy as possible.

"Butter On Commission." 
  The market is in light stock and quick sale for fresh make and also for choice entire dairies. Selections of Creamerie and Orange Cy.  advanced yesterday to 40 cts., and this sets most buyers looking for something good enough at less price. 
  Fine middle and Southern tier County fall butter sells at 35 cts., and choice entire dairies at 32 @ 35 cts., and fine Welch make, if here, would bring close to same prices, but ordinary picked up lots of Northern Welch, such as is coming here, is only worth 29 @ 30 cts. 
  The opening figures are higher than last year, with prospect of a high toned fall and winter market. Yours truly, 
  David W. Lewis & Co., 
  85 & 87 Broad Street.

  Waukesha  Aug 31 
  Dear Sister 

I take this present oportunity  to write you these few lines to let you know that I am well and in hope this  will find you the same I did not receive but one from home since I broke  my leg and that was from you I heard that Bill wrote Aunt Mary Ann but she  dont say a word about it dont you never write my leters in care of know? one again or if you will you might  as well not write at all  I don't know when I shall  get them and be sure and  spell the direction right

they will be mad at the Post office if you want my leg is get in along very well now I can walk with one cane now I was in the hop yard yeserday all day with my girl as my wife for she will be one the 5th of next October it is true you can believe me or not I thought you were mad at so I went for a wife because I dont want be such shape if I happen to got sick I have some one to take care if better than I did when I broke my leg to be left alone all day. I did not like that but if you want me to come home send me money and I will come I told you how much I wanted

I tell you that wanted twenty five dollr the Doctor Charge me thirty five or I could come without any but now I must twenty five dollr if you dont want me you at home neednt send but if you send I shall come I shall go to work hop picking next week 
I shall change my Address 
Evan R Pritchard        
Delafield        
Wankesha             
Wis 
you tell Bob Thomas that must hurry up if wants to come to my wedding and send my best respect to all and write soon

Whitestown Feb 18th 1872
Wm R Pritchard.
Dear Sir: I have kept of writing till now for one reason as other I was sick yesterday all day with the cold but I am so as to be around today. I had a letter from Evan today at this I suppose you will ask me where he is. he is out west he started from here last tuesday morning week from today while I was in the chaple without telling anything and when I came from the chaple I saw that he and his trunk were gone he arrived there safe on Thursday of last week

I didnt write to you because that I new that it would not do you a bit of good it was rather unexpected to me and I suppose it will be to you I gave him twenty-five dollars. I didnt think that he was going to do what did with it. You must not blame me for I didnt know anything about it till after he had gone. I dont know but what you have heard of it before. I have enough victuals for a week I havent been down to Uttica since week ago last Monday I will write to you to tell you to send victuals dont sent till I sent another

letter. The snow is going off here but - I suppose you have got - enough of it - so -then why my letter is getting long you must - write- soon
This from
S.E. Pritchard
Whitestown Sem
Oneida Co
NY

April 3
   Wm. R Pritchard
      Dear friend

I take this oportunity to write you these lines to let you that I am well and enjoying myself very well. I am at work at present in a good place best place that I ever I received Eliza and George letter it is very mudy herre now so it is awful bad to go around I health is good better than it was when I was to school where is george now is he to school when I will come back I shall stay now I cant tell when that

will be I guess it wood be very soon when the pleant? will I shall be back I was to my aunt yesterday they were all well I am to church three times every sunday this is all at present from 
E R Pritchard
Waukesha
Wis
